description: The full title of the research product and its abbreviations or aliases.
Brief text that describes the research product, its content and main features.
The research product’s creator(s). It may be a single person, a group of people or an organisation.
A person, group, or organisation that has contributed to the creation or development of the research product.
The publisher of the research product. It may also be a university or other institution hosting the research product.
An additional RDF class for the item, providing more specific classification.
The type of research product, specified using a term from a controlled vocabulary.
A unique identifier of the research product. The same research product can be assigned multiple identifiers of different kinds.
The date the research product was released.
The language(s) in which the research product is expressed.
The file format(s) in which the research product’s data are stored.
range Restriction: EU Vocabularies - File Type | IANA Media Types

description: Standards to which the research product’s metadata conform.
The research product’s status in its lifecycle.
A research product that forms part of the catalogued one.
Inverse of Has Part this field indicates the research product of which the catalogued one is a component.
The academic field(s) to which the research product pertains.
Research activities enabled or supported by the research product.
Research activities conducted to create or develop the research product.
The URL of the download or download page of the research product’s files.
The number of the research product’s current version.

A standardized size of a product, expressed as the number of individual texts, tokens or other items. For clarity, the value must include the unit of measurement, e.g, “500 documents”, “230.000 tokens”.
The URL of the web page where the research product is presented, and is possible to access its distributions.
URL of a publication that describes or reviews the research product.
The research project within which the research product was created.
Software tools or other research products used to create or develop the research product.
URL of the website or data service (e.g., API, SPARQL endpoint) that grants access to the research product.
The URL of the research product’s documentation.
This field indicates how the research product may be accessed. If multiple access rights exist, use this field to specify access for the main part of the product.
The licence under which the research product is available to the public.
Additional information about the Research Product
A set of entities to which the research product contains a reference.
URI of the cataloguing record of the edited work.

Properties: Original document(s) or witness(es) available at (M)
description: The URL of a web resource presenting as digital facsimile the document(s) or witness(es) on which the edition is based.
URI of the cataloguing record of the edited text’s author.
The type(s) of edition. This indicates the editorial approach taken by the team and the main objectives of the edition.
The genre(s) of the edited text.
The URL to the documents’ or witnesses’ facsimile(s) provided within the catalogued edition, if applicable.
URIs of the ontologies and vocabularies employed in data modelling.
URI of the cataloguing records of the works included in the text collection, if applicable.
The place(s) which are the focus of the text collection’s content
The period that the text collection’s content applies to.
The main author(s) of the edited text(s). If the edition is 'document-centric' it is possible to indicate the hand(s).
URI of the cataloguing record(s) of the author(s) of the texts included in the text collection.
The genre(s) of the collected texts.
The namespace used by the terms of the ontology.
Ontologies or vocabularies imported or partially reused by the catalogued ontology.
The file format(s) of data the software can process as input, if applicable.
The file format(s) of data the software can generate as output, if applicable.
The URL of the source code’s repository (e.g., GitHub, Zenodo, FigShare).
The programming language(s) employed in the software’s development.
Software component(s) used or extended in the catalogued software.
URI(s) of the task(s) that can be carried out by employing the language model.
URIs of the machine learning libraries utilised for the development, training, evaluation, or deployment of the model.
One or multiple files providing a 3D representation of the Cultural Heritage Object
The Cultural Heritage Object represented by the 3D Digital Twin
